Upgrading carbon dioxide (CO2) into valuable products is a highly promising strategy of artificial carbon cycle. In this study, a series of in situ reduced CuMgAl layered double hydroxides (R-CuMgAl-LDHs) composites were synthesized, in which Cu nanoparticles were effectively dispersed and anchored on MgAl-LDHs with formation of Cu+ and Cu0 species. The optimized R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the carboxylative cyclization of 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol with CO2 (turnover number of 243) under mild conditions. The layered structure of LDH stabilized the active Cu species with high dispersion, enhancing the catalytic efficiency of this carboxylative cyclization reaction. Simultaneously, the dual-activation of both CO2 and propargylic alcohol by Cu0/Cu+ species generated on the surface of LDH contributed significantly to the catalytic efficiency enhancement. Furthermore, R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH catalyzed the reaction of a wide range of terminal or internal propargyl alcohols with CO2, yielding various functionalized α-alkylene cyclic carbonates. Finally, a reasonable reaction mechanism was put forward according to the comprehensive analysis. Conversely, CO2 can serve as a potential valuable C1 synthon, based on advantageous properties of low cost, nontoxicity, abundance and renewability. Hence, carbon dioxide utilization strategies have attracted global attention [4–12]. A wide range of high-value chemicals and fuels, such as organic carbonates [13–16], carboxylic acids [17,18], formic acid [19] and alcohols [20–22] are produced through various CO2 chemical fixation strategies. Among these chemicals, organic carbonates, originated from the cycloaddition of epoxide/CO2 and the carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohol/CO2, have been becoming appealing in the field of CO2 utilization, since the targeted products provide commercial value in both the biomedical industry and pharmaceutical chemistry [23–26]. To date, many efforts have focused on discovering efficient catalysts used in the carboxylative cyclization reaction to afford α-alkylene cyclic carbonates. As listed in Table S1, various catalytic systems, such as transition metals, ionic liquids (ILs) [27,28], CO2-adducts [29,30] and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [31] have been widely studied in the cyclization of CO2 and propargyl alcohol. Transition metals (such as Ag, Pd, Cu, and Zn) demonstrate unique advantages in catalyzing carboxylative cyclization [32–38]. Compared to noble metals, such as silver and palladium, copper as an inexpensive non-noble metal element, has become a research hotspot in catalyzing carboxylative cyclization, as ascribed by the capacity of Cu+ in activating the CC triple bonds of propargyl alcohol [39–41]. On the other hand, it is well accepted that Cu0 region contributes significantly to both CO2 absorption and activation [42,43]. Nevertheless, there are still some disadvantages with copper-based catalysts, such as harsh reaction conditions are often required in the process of catalyst synthesis. Besides this, it is very difficult to predict and control the impacts of additives, ligands or functional supports on the reaction. Therefore, designing efficient and environmentally friendly copper-based catalysts is the key to efficiently afford α-alkylene cyclic carbonates. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are a group of anionic clay minerals, consisting of a positively charged matrix layer with metal hydroxides and exchangeable interlayer regions with compensation anions and solvated molecules [44–46]. LDHs as catalysts have received great attention in various catalytic reactions, namely, the conversion of CO2. LDHs have tunable basicity, large specific surface area and excellent adsorption capacity, which facilitate the adsorption of CO2 and other substrates [47–49]. Furthermore, the structural diversity enables LDHs to be fine-tuned for specific catalytic applications. For example, copper based ternary LDHs have Cu(OH)6 units in the 2D layered structure, which are suitable precursors for the preparation of Cu-based catalysts [50]. More importantly, through the in situ reduction process, only Cu2+ ions are separated from the host layer and transformed into Cu+ or Cu0 species. Meanwhile, the remaining other metallic ions maintain the layered structure of the LDH, which can further anchor and disperse the active Cu+ or Cu0 species and have strong metal-support interaction [51]. Motivated by these promising characteristics, we aimed to investigate copper based ternary LDHs as an excellent class of catalysts for the cyclization of propargyl alcohol with CO2. In this work, we have developed a new heterogeneous catalyst, denoted as R-CuMgAl-LDH, with Cu nanoparticles immobilized on MgAl-LDH by an in situ reduction approach ( Fig. 1), where the Cu-supported nanoparticles are able to enhance the catalytic performance for the carboxylative cyclization reaction based on comparative studies. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited good recyclability and wide substrate scope for the synthesis of various α-alkylene cyclic carbonates. A combination study including material characterizations and comparative experiments reveals that: (1) Cu nanoparticles are effectively dispersed and anchored on MgAl-LDH with the formation of Cu+ and Cu0 active species. (2) The dual-activation of both substrates by of Cu0/Cu+ species and the layered structure of LDHs greatly enhance the catalytic efficiency for the carboxylative cyclization of CO2 and propargyl alcohol. Lastly, a reasonable reaction mechanism in R-CuMgAl-LDH was also proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All terminal propargyl alcohols are commercially available from Macklin Scientific Ltd, TCI Scientific Ltd, and J&K Scientific Ltd. Cuprous oxide, copper oxide, and nano copper powder were purchased from Aladdin Scientific Ltd. 2-Methyl-4-phenylbut-3-yn-2-ol and 3-ethyl-1-phenylpent-1-yn-3-ol were synthesized according to previous reports [52]. Sodium hydroxide, sodium carbonate, magnesium nitrate hexahydrate, copper nitrate trihydrate, aluminum nitrate heptahydrate, and hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O) were purchased from Putian Biotechnology Company (Tai’an, China). All of the materials above were of analytical grade and used directly without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of CuxMg3−xAl1-LDH precursors Several CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs (x = 0, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 3.0) have been prepared as below. Typically, for the synthesis of Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDHs, 120 mL salt solution (Cu(NO3)2.5 H2O, 15 mmol; Mg(NO3)2.6 H2O, 15 mmol; Al(NO3)3.9 H2O, 10 mmol) was drop-wisely added to 50 mL Na2CO3 solution (0.166 mol/L). 1 M NaOH solution was added to adjust the pH value to 9–11. The resulting suspensions were then heated at 60 oC in an oil bath under continuous magnetic stirring for 3 h. The precipitates were filtered, and then were dispersed in the 2.00 mol/L Na2CO3 solution (50 mL) at 40 oC under continuous magnetic stirring for 12 h. The precipitates were filtered and washed with deionized water thoroughly. And then, the obtained precipitates was dispersed in ethanol solution under stirring for 2 h, and filtered to obtain the wet solid CuMgAl-LDHs, which were dried at 100 °C overnight. 2.3 R-CuxMg3−xAl1-LDH reduced by hydrazine hydrate The in situ reduced CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs, marked as R-CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs, were obtained by the in situ reduction of CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs precursors using hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O) as a reducing agent. Briefly, 100 mg of CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs precursors were dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water to form an LDH suspension in a round-bottomed flask, and then hydrazine hydrate (0.5 mL) was added. The mixed solution was then heated at 90 oC in an oil bath under continuous magnetic stirring for 2 h. The suspension was collected by centrifugation and washed several times with deionized water. Finally, the R-CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs were obtained after drying overnight in a vacuum at 70 oC. Meanwhile, R-Cu1.5Zn1.5Al1-LDH catalyst was obtained by the in situ reduction of Cu1.5Zn1.5Al1-LDH precursors with hydrazine under the same conditions. 2.4 R-Cu2O/Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH reduced by ascorbic acid Initially, NaOH/Na2CO3 mixed solution (2:1 molar ratio, M(Na+) = 4.0 mol/L) was added to 50 mL 0.2 mol/L ascorbic aqueous solution until the pH value was adjusted to 8.9–9.1. And then, 50 mL aqueous solution, in which Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (100 mg) was dispersed, was added drop-wisely to the obtained ascorbic solution. The suspension was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Subsequently, the suspension was centrifuged and washed with water (at least 3 times). Finally, R-Cu2O/Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was obtained by dried in vacuum at 60 oC, 12 h, in which only Cu2O was generated. 2.5 The recovery of catalysts The R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was collected by filtration and washed with ethanol and dried in vacuum. Then the catalyst was reduced by hydrazine hydrate and reused in the continuous runs. 2.6 Characterization The crystal phase and chemical structure information of the samples were measured by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The morphologies structures of the samples were measured by a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The elemental compositions of catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP). The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) approach. 2.7 Typical procedure for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate Briefly, R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (12.8 mg, 5.0 mol%) was loaded into a Schlenk tube and the air in tube was replaced with CO2 by a Schlenk line. Then 1a (1.0 mmol, 84.1 mg), DBU (1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene) (1.0 mmol, 152.2 mg) and acetonitrile (3 mL) were added and stirred for 5 h at 30 oC. When the reaction was finished, the solution was filtered and analyzed by gas chromatography with biphenyl as the internal standard. The targeted products were purified by column chromatography and characterized by NMR spectroscopy with CDCl3 as the solvent. 2.8 Gram-scale experiment 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (1a, 50.0 mmol, 4206.0 mg), DBU (12.5 mmol, 1903.0 mg), R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (12.8 mg, 5.0 mol%) and acetonitrile (40.0 mL) were loaded into a Schlenk tube with CO2 balloon. Then the system was kept stirring at 0 oC for 3 days. After the reaction, the mixture was analyzed by gas chromatography with biphenyl as the internal standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization As shown in Fig. 1, a series of CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs (x = 0, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 3.0) precursors and in situ reduced CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs (marked as R-CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs) were synthesized by a facile aqueous co-precipitation method and in situ reduction process. It is obvious that after reduction, the color of the sample changes from black to dark red (Fig. S1). Details of the preparation process are described in Experimental Section. The structure and morphology of CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs (x = 0, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 3.0) were investigated by various methods. Fig. 2a gives the powder XRD patterns of CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs with different Cu/Mg molar ratios. Diffraction peaks of all samples appear at 11.5o, 23o and 34.5o, which are attributed to the characteristic peaks of d(003), d(006), and d(012) crystal surfaces of LDH, respectively, indicating that CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs with good layered structures were successfully prepared by the coprecipitation method [53]. In addition, well-defined diffraction peaks at 60.4o and 61.6o, respectively, show good dispersion of both anions and cations in brucite-like layers. The results are consistent with those of CO3 2--type LDHs reported previously [54]. Furthermore, with increasing Cu content (x), the typical diffraction peaks indexed to the LDH appeared to decrease and broaden, indicating decreased crystallinity of the LDH. More obviously, with increasing Cu/Mg molar ratios, the diffraction peak of CuO appears, and the intensity increases. This is due to the fact that the ion radius of Cu2+ is larger than that of Mg2+, which leads to the Jahn-Teller effect, thus forming CuO and further destroying the layered structure [55]. In Fig. 2b, XRD patterns of in situ reduced CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs (x = 0, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 3.0), marked as R-CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs, are depicted. Except the Mg3Al1-LDH, the diffraction peak of metallic copper appears after the CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs were reduced by N2H4·H2O, and the intensities of the diffraction peaks and crystallinity increase with increasing x value. Meanwhile, the structure of the LDH phase exhibited no change. However, the diffractions at 60.4o and 61.6o attributable to LDH phases became less obvious after reduction, indicating that the copper species within the host layers were reduced and the lattice defects of LDH backbones may be obtained in the reduction process. Besides, Fig. S2 showed the X-ray diffraction patterns of both Cu1.5Zn1.5Al1-LDH and R-Cu1.5Zn1.5Al1-LDH, revealing the corresponding diffraction peaks of LDH and Cu, respectively. These results suggest that Cu nanoparticles had been successfully fixed on the LDH and the LDH phase remained unchanged after the reduction process. To further confirm the structure and coordination environment of these samples, the FT-IR spectra of several representative samples were investigated. As shown in Fig. 3a, all spectra showed a wide absorption peak at 3480 cm-1, induced by the telescopic vibration absorption of hydroxyl (O-H) on the LDH layers and interlayer water [56]. The absorption peak at 1600 cm-1 can be attributed to the bending vibration of hydroxyl. A strong absorption peak at 1360 cm-1 was assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibration of CO3 2- [57]. In the low-frequency region, two vibration peaks appearing at 750 cm-1 and 590 cm-1 were attributed to the vibrations of M-O and M-OH modes in the LDH lattice, respectively [58]. The above results verify that the structure of the representative Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH before and after the in situ reduction was consistent with Mg3Al1-LDH, unambiguously suggesting that the introduction of Cu2+ and the formation of Cu0 did not change the LDH phase. To determine the surface areas of the CuMgAl-LDHs, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of several representative samples were evaluated. The Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH presented type II with H3 type hysteresis loops, indicating the existence of mesoporous structures (Fig. 3b), similar to the pure Mg3Al1-LDH material [59]. These results were confirmed by the pore size distribution (Table S2). The specific surface area of Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH were 103 and 86 m2 g-1, respectively. Furthermore, although the specific surface area was less than that of Mg3Al1-LDH, the value is still within the normal range of the LDHs’ surface areas. XPS spectra were conducted to further verify the Cu species in Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH before and after the reduction process. As shown in Fig. S2, the survey spectra of two samples further showed that C, O, Mg, Al, and Cu elements were the main components. Furthermore, the position and strength of the binding energies of Mg and Al remained unchanged before and after the reduction reaction (Fig. S3), indicating that the reduction reaction did not affect the structure of the LDH. For the Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (Fig. 3c), this was observed at the Cu 2p3/2 peak at 934.9 eV and the Cu 2p1/2 peak at 954.7 eV, corresponding to Cu2+ species [60]. While, for R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks shifted to 932.5 eV and 952.4 eV, ascribed to the Cu0 or Cu+ species [61]. Meanwhile, the intensity of the Cu2+ satellite peaks of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH decreased, indicating that a portion of the Cu2+ content was reduced to Cu+ or Cu0. Due to the difficulty in distinguishing Cu+ from Cu0 based on the binding energy of Cu 2p signals, we further conducted Cu LMM X-ray auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) in the kinetic energy range of 905–925 eV (Fig. 3d). For Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, an overlapping peak at 917.7 eV was observed in the Cu LMM Auger electron spectroscopies, which can be assigned to Cu2+. Furthermore, the Cu LMM Auger spectra of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was resolved into two peaks at the kinetic energies of 916.0 eV and 918.8 eV, corresponding to Cu+ and Cu0, respectively [62,63]. And, the Auger parameter of Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0 were 1852.6, 1848.3 eV and 1851.1 eV, respectively (Table S4). The above test data agreed with the corresponding Auger parameter of different copper species [64]. The deconvolution of the Cu LMM Auger spectra of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was determined to be about 0.78:1 for Cu+/Cu0. The result implied that a large number of Cu+ species exist on the surface of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, which can help to activate the CC triple bond and improve the catalytic performance of the carboxylative cyclization [40,65]. The result implied that a large number of Cu+ species exist on the surface of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, consistent with the results of the Cu 2p XPS spectra. In addition, the characteristic peaks of Cu2O were not observed in the XRD patterns of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (data not shown), which implied that the Cu2O could be amorphous. As shown in the SEM and TEM images in Fig. 4a–f and Fig. S5, the samples have thin plate-shaped crystalline morphology with layered structures. Upon reduction, the shapes of the brucite-like layers were maintained, but some independent particles were clearly observed to be grafted on the surface of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (Fig. 4f). From Fig. S6, we can determine that an average particle size of the particles was about 3.27 nm. Additionally, the interplanar spacing of 0.208 nm can be observed by high-resolution TEM (Fig. 4g and Fig. S7), which are consistent with the interplanar distance of the Cu (111) crystallographic plan [66]. In addition, no diffraction patterns of Cu+ species were found, further confirming that Cu+ species was an amorphous feature, which was consistent with the results of XRD test. Due to the layered structures in R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, Cu nanoparticles were highly dispersed and tightly anchored on the sample. Moreover, homogeneous distribution of Cu, Mg, and Al in the particle was confirmed by element mapping images (Fig. 4i–k). As shown in Fig. 4l, the presence of Cu, Mg, and Al, as well as the chemical composition, were investigated by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopic (ICP-AES) analysis yielding a molar ratio of Cu, Mg, and Al of about 1.5:1.5:1. These results strongly indicate that the Cu particles were uniformly distributed on the LDH frameworks and the in situ reduction process did not change the structure of the CuMgAl-LDH. 3.2 Carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohols with CO2 3.2.1 Reaction condition optimization To explore the catalytic capacity of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDHs for carboxylative cyclization, 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (1a) was chosen as the model substrate to obtain optimal conditions. The catalytic activities of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH were closely investigated under various conditions, and the results are listed in Table S3. Neither R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH nor DBU had catalytic activities individually under the given conditions (entries 1–2, Table S3). Interestingly, the integration of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and DBU provided excellent yield (92%, entry 3, Table S3). Furthermore, the concentrations of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and DBU could be reduced to 5.0 mol% and 0.25 equivalent, respectively, while retaining excellent yields (entries 4–20, Table S3). The CO2 pressure dependency was tested (entry 21 and 22, Table. S3). Under higher CO2 pressure (0.5 Mpa and 1.0 Mpa), similar yields (84%, 86%) were obtained compared with those under 0.1 Mpa (atmospheric CO2). Based on these results, R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was proven to be an efficient catalyst for carboxylative cyclization to afford the targeted cyclic carbonates. In addition, although R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH exhibited local surface plasma effect (Fig. S8), it did not show photocatalytic performance in the reaction (entry 16, Table S3). 3.2.2 Comparisons of different catalysts The catalytic performance of carboxylative cyclization with different catalysts was compared ( Table 1). The Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH precursor was first tested, and no targeted 2a was obtained (entry 1), indicating the Cu2+ species were not active catalysts for this reaction system, which agrees with the results of commercial CuO as the catalyst (entry 2). Meanwhile, R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, in which both Cu0 species and Cu2O were generated, exhibited a good performance (89%, entry 3), suggesting individual Cu0/Cu+ species or their dual-activation effect played a key role in this reaction. Based on previous literature, Cu+ species are believed to be active catalytic sites by activating the CC triple bonds for carboxylative cyclization [40,65]. In this catalytic system, Cu2O is generated on the R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH. However, when Cu2O was applied, a poor yield (7%) was obtained (entry 5). In addition, ascorbic acid-reduced R-Cu2O/Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, in which only Cu2O is generated (Fig. S9), provided 62% yield (entry 6), which is much higher than that of sole Cu2O (entry 5), and lower than that of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (entry 3) reduced by N2H4·H2O. These results suggest that layer-structured LDH enhanced the catalytic efficiency of Cu2O, but it was not the sole contributor to the high catalytic efficiency of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH. Therefore, the dual-activation of both CO2 and propargyl alcohol by Cu0/Cu2O is proposed. Subsequently, nano Cu0 powder was also explored, affording 60% yield (entry 7), revealing that Cu0 sites are also critical for the carboxylative cyclization. Furthermore, based on the XPS results (Fig. S10), there are Cu+ species on the surface nano Cu0 powder, further demonstrating the dual-activation role of both Cu0 and Cu+ species. Subsequently, we investigated the effect of Cu+/Cu0 ratio on R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH by employing different dosages of hydrazine hydrate. Similar catalytic performances were obtained with yields of 86%− 89% (entries 3, 8–10). It probably was ascribed that the content of active Cu+ species for activating CC triple bonds was almost not effected by Cu+/Cu0 ratio, since the amorphous active Cu+ species mainly distributed on the surface of Cu nanoparticles. R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH catalyst obtained by the in situ reduction of Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH precursors using sodium borohydride (NaBH4) as a strong reducing agent, can afford 63% yield (entry 11), which was similar to that of nano Cu0 powder (entry 7). In addition, the ratio of Cu/Mg/Al was also investigated (5 mol% catalyst loading based on Cu species, entries 3, 12–14). Relatively good yields (82%) were found, which were slightly lower than that of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH. It indicated the ratio of Cu species did not lead to obvious change of the layered structure of LDH (Fig. 2b), retaining the good catalytic performance. We also chose other LDH materials. R-Cu1.5Zn1.5Al1-LDH can afford 46% yield under the same reaction conditions (entry 15). Again, these results indicate that the special layered structure of LDH can confine and stabilize active Cu species with high dispersion, which can improve the activity and utilization of catalysts. Moreover, the catalytic efficiency of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was also investigated in gram-scale experiments with 1a as the substrate (seen in Experimental section). The TON (turnover of number) value reached 243, which is higher than those of individual Cu-based catalysts (Table S1). 3.2.3 Substrate scope With the optimized conditions, the exploration of the substrate scope of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was performed. As summarized in Scheme 1, different types of terminal propargyl alcohols were validated under optimal conditions. Excellent applicability was found for different types of terminal propargyl alcohols, and high isolated yields (> 80%) were obtained for all substrates with chain/cyclic moieties (2a-2h). Notably, internal propargyl alcohol substrates, which are usually less active than terminal ones, can also achieve good yields by way of prolonged time and enhanced CO2 pressure (2i, 2j). 3.2.4 Catalyst recyclability Afterward, the recyclability and stability of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH were evaluated. R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was recycled by a reductive activation process and used for subsequent runs. As shown in Fig. S11, no significant loss of catalytic activity was observed after four cycles, and only a slight decrease occurred in the conversion of 1a (the yield was ranged from 89% to 82% after four cycles). We used ICP-OES to detect the leaching copper ions of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH. The ICP detection exhibited that the amount of copper species dropped from 0.278 mg/mg to 0.203 mg/mg, which was possibly attributed to that the leaching of copper and can explain the slight decrease in catalytic activity. SEM and TEM images obtained for R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH after four catalytic cycles showed no obvious change in morphology with partial aggregation ( Fig. 5f and Fig. S12a). After four runs, the XRD patterns and XPS spectra (Fig. S12b and c) showed that the structure and valence state of the catalyst were almost the same except that the intensity of the Cu species weakened, confirming the high reusability of the catalyst under reaction conditions by a reductive activation process. Taken altogether, R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH can serve as an efficient catalyst with good recyclability for the carboxylative cyclization of various terminal and non-terminal propargyl alcohols under mild conditions. 3.2.5 Proposed mechanism To uncover the mechanism, the interaction among propargyl alcohol 1a, DBU and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was monitored by NMR measurements (Fig. 5). The 1H signal of hydroxyl group (-OH) in 1a disappeared after the addition of DBU and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (Fig. 5a). It could be attributed to the capture of proton in -OH by DBU, providing evidences on the activation of -OH by DBU, which was agreement with previous reports [67,68]. As seen in Fig. 5b-c, the changes in 13C NMR spectra (from δ = 90.31, 70.48–91.27, 70.01 ppm) could be ascribed to the activation of propargyl alcohol 1a by DBU (proton capture from 1a) and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (the interaction with CC bond). Based on these results, the good catalytic performance of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH reaction system can be attributed to the following aspects. (1) R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH has high specific surface area and adsorption capacity, which is beneficial to adsorb CO2 molecules and propargyl alcohols [69]. Notably, the special layered structure of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH can stabilize and disperse Cu nanoparticles into small sizes. (2) DBU could activate propargyl alcohol by capturing proton from hydroxy group. (3) The Cu0 and amorphous Cu+ species on LDH could simultaneously absorb and activate CO2 and propargylic alcohol, respectively [42,43]. Generally, adsorption capacity of material for CO2 molecules may affect the catalytic CO2 conversion. The CO2 adsorption properties of Mg3Al1-LDH, Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH at 298 K were initially examined. As displayed in Fig. S13, the Mg3Al1-LDH afforded a higher adsorption capacity for CO2 (28.36 cm³/g). Remarkably, as compared to the Mg3Al1-LDH, the Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (10.42 cm³/g) and R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (12.44 cm³/g) presented significant decrease of CO2 adsorption. This result indicated that the introduction of copper species reduced the adsorption capacity of LDH, which is similar to the BET test results. Note, however, the CO2 adsorption property of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was higher than that of Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, which could be attributed to the fact that the abundant he low-price copper species might function as CO2 adsorption sites through the interaction with CO2 molecules due to their high surface binding energy. Taking these results and published literatures together, a possible mechanism was proposed as shown in Fig. 6. Benefiting from the high adsorption capacity and abundant active sites of LDH, CO2 and propargylic alcohol were absorbed to the surface of Cu nanoparticals and thereby activated by the Cu0 and Cu+ species, respectively [42,43]. Second, the propargylic carbonate anion A was formed in the aid of DBU on the surface of R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, facilitating the nucleophilic attack of A to CO2 molecule to generate the intermediate B. Subsequently, the CC triple bond activated by Cu+ species was attacked by the oxygen anion of intermediate B to undergo an intramolecular ring-closing step to obtain intermediate C. Finally, the cyclic carbonate was obtained while the R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH entered the next catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusion LDHs (R-CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs) were prepared via an in situ reduction process from corresponding CuxMg3−xAl1-LDHs precursors. The formation of Cu nanoparticles are effectively dispersed and anchored on MgAl-LDH with the formation of Cu+ and Cu0 active species. The obtained R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH exhibited excellent catalytic performance under optimal conditions, attributable to the layered structure of LDH with enhanced adsorption capacity and the dual-activation capacities of both substrates by Cu0/Cu+ species. In addition, the recyclability of the catalyst can be maintained. Moreover, the R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH exhibited wide substrate scope in the synthesis of various α-alkylene cyclic carbonates. This research provides a reference for further development of Cu-based heterogeneous catalysts in upgrading carbon dioxide. coredata.dc:description: Upgrading carbon dioxide (CO2) into valuable products is a highly promising strategy of artificial carbon cycle. In this study, a series of in situ reduced CuMgAl layered double hydroxides (R-CuMgAl-LDHs) composites were synthesized, in which Cu nanoparticles were effectively dispersed and anchored on MgAl-LDHs with formation of Cu+ and Cu0 species. The optimized R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the carboxylative cyclization of 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol with CO2 (turnover number of 243) under mild conditions. The layered structure of LDH stabilized the active Cu species with high dispersion, enhancing the catalytic efficiency of this carboxylative cyclization reaction. Simultaneously, the dual-activation of both CO2 and propargylic alcohol by Cu0/Cu+ species generated on the surface of LDH contributed significantly to the catalytic efficiency enhancement. Furthermore, R-Cu1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH catalyzed the reaction of a wide range of terminal or internal propargyl alcohols with CO2, yielding various functionalized α-alkylene cyclic carbonates. Finally, a reasonable reaction mechanism was put forward according to the comprehensive analysis.
coredata.dc:title: Cu nanoparticles-dispersed Mg-Al layered double hydroxides as efficient catalysts for CO2 conversion with propargyl alcohols
